JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 7.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 18, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRISON CONFERENCE ENDS

LIBRARY IN GILMAN BUILDING

HOPKINS ROOTING WAS GOOD

ST. JOHN'S, 27; JOHNS HOPKINS, 7

Thursday Last Day of Convention—Officers Elected and Indianapolis Chosen
for Place of Next Meeting.

Rooms Will First Be Used for Classes,
but Later Books Will Be Installed
in the Structure.

Parade One of the Best Ever Held, and
Cheering Section at Homewood
Was Crowded.

Losers Have Best of It in Straight
Football —Great Crowd and Much
Enthusiasm at Homewood.

The annual meeting of the American-Prison Association, whose sessions started in McCoy Hall on
Saturday, November 9, came to an
end on Thursday, the fourteenth,
after a most beneficial series of
conferences.
The objects of this society are,
according to the program issued:
first, to improve the laws relating
to crime and their enforcement;
second, to study the causes and
methods of preventing crime; third,
to improve conditions in penal institutions, and, fourth, aid discharged
Prisoners in obtaining employment,
and in reforming their lives.
The addresses were made by authorities on all these lines and were
confined to these and subjects
closely akin. It seemed to be the
Opinion of many members at the
meeting that the criminal is responsible neither mentally nor morally;
this point was brought out by sev,eral speakers.
Among the persons who made
addresses were: Mrs. Maud Ballington Booth; John D. Lawson,
Dean of the Law School of the
University of Missouri; Dr. H. H.
Hart, Director of the Child-helping
Department of the Russell Sage
Foundation.
Election of officers for the comMr.
ing year (1913) was held.
James A. Leonard was elected
president to succeed Mr. Fred G.
Pettigrove of Boston. Mr. Leonard
has been for many years the warden
of the Ohio State Reformatory at
Mansfield, 0.
Dr. D. C. Peyton of Jeffersonville, Ind., was elected vice-president and Mr. Joseph P. Byers was
elected secretary.

Parker, Thomas & Rice, the architects of the Gilman Building, which
will be the first of the new Homewood quadrangle to be erected, have
not yet finished specifications and
building plans.
As soon as these papers are ready
the Board of Trustees will let the
contracts and the actual building
will . begin. It was stated in an.
article last week that the Gilman
Building was not to contain the
University library. Ultimately, the
library will be in this building, but
the rooms will have to first be used
as lecture rooms until the other
buildings are erected. Then when
the "quad" is finished the library
will be moved into the Gilman
Building.
It is understood that after the
contracts for this building are let the
Trustees will examine plans for the
four scientific laboratories and the
technical buildings. Drawings for
these are ready, and the Board will
hold a special meeting to consider
them in the near future. The Gilman Building will be the western
end of the "quad" and two laboratories on a side will form the north
and south sides. The eastern end
will not be closed until later.
Extending southwards from the
laboratories will be the technical
buildings in the form of another
quadrangle.
The contour of the Homewood
Estate will be preserved as much as
possible in the erection of the buildings. The tract is one of the prettiest natural parks about Baltimore,
and many of the trustees favored the
plan of erecting the buildings to
conform to the ground.
Few of the old trees on the estate
will be cut down, and the "quad
will have surrounding it trees larger
than the Old Elms at Yale.

Too much cannot be said in praise
of the great amount of college
spirit manifested by Hopkins, both
in the parade and at Homewood,
last Saturday. The better part of
the undergraduate student body,
with the exception of the players
and others who were acting in official positions, responded nobly to
the appeals that were made at the
mass-meetings during the week.
That a great awakening had
taken place at Hopkins was evident
to all, and particularly to the regular spectators at Homewood. They
contrasted the spirit shown last
Saturday with that at the preceding games at Homewood, and were
very much pleased with the difference.
A culmination of the spirit which
began to develop at Tuesday's
mass-meeting was reached on Saturday. The singing of songs during the intervals between classes
had much to do with stirring up the
enthusiasm displayed by Hopkins.
The mass-meeting at Homewood
Friday afternoon was better attended than any for many years.
Those who assembled at Homewood on Friday sat for more than
a half hour in the cold grandstand
after dark, cheering the 'Varsity
eleven as it ran through its final
signal drill.
Emrich's band was a decided success, and Manager Ellis Ellicott and
"Gus" Sattler should be congratulated on their choice. The parade
began assembling between twelve
and one o'clock, and although it
did not start until after half past
one, everyone joined in the intermittent yells and songs which were
given every few moments.
When the parade did start it was
at once apparent that it was the
best that has been held for several
years. New features were introduced, especially by the sophomore
class, a number of whose members
formed a kettle drum division, each
being equipped with large tin dishes
and wooden spoons, which were
used as drumsticks.
' The sophomores also had secured
a very vociferously blatant, cacoplionious goat, which was the principal feature of the whole parade.
Headed by Emr,ich's band the paraders started following in the
order of classes, although many
alumni were interspersed at various
points. Edward Novak was the
standard bearer of the seniors, and
they followed immediately behind

fter being defeated three years
in succession by Hopkins' teams, St.
John's College, the 'Varsity's oldest
and bitterest rival got vendrtta last
Saturday at Homewood, 27 to 7.
Forward passes won the game
for the cadets, and their work in
this department has not been
equalled on the Homewood Field,
except, perhaps, by Twig-g of_Western Maryland, whose long thrOWs
last season were spectacular and
won the game then. To Wilson,
the St. John's left halfback, who
threw the passes Saturday, belongs
the credit for the victory.
The throws were not for long
distances; they were not spectacular because of the distance they
made, but the were accurate, lefthanded, timely and sped like a baseball. The four winning touchdowns
had for their direct source a beautiful forward pass. Three times Mellon carried the ball over after receiving from Wilson, and Claude
carried the fourth.
Hopkins did not use the forward
pass successfully, however, but in
all other respects played on a par
with the Annapolis players. Hopkins frequently had the ball in St.
John's territory near the goal, but
the cadets' barrier was impenetrable;
end runs and line plays could not
gain ground, and the 'Varsity was
forced to give up the ball.
In a like manner, St. John's
worked the ball upfield to within the
shadow of the Hopkins goal. The
'Varsity line held, and St. John's
could not gain on an end run. It
was at these crises that a forward
pass was called and a touchdown
made. Once in each period the
Annapolis team scored. Hopkins
made its touchdown in the last
quarter.
Line plays, with Branham and
G. Penniman carrying the ball,
brought Hopkins up to within 12
yards of the St. John's goal. Tappan tried a forward pass, which
Mellon intercepted, and a groan
went up from Hopkins rooters.
Clayton received the ball to punt
out, but the Hopkins line broke
through, and a trio of linemen
blocked the kick. The ball went
over the goal line and in a minute
Frankie La Motte had it tucked
under his arm, saving the 'Varsity
from the ignominy of a whitewash.
Newspaper reports said that Liebensperger and Bridgman blocked
the kick. It was a hard play to see,
but the general opinion is that both

Federated Charities.

On Tuesday, November 26, at 8
P. M., the annual public meeting of
the Federated Charities will be held
in McCoy Hall. The president,,,
Gen. Lawrason Riggs, will occupy',"
the chair. The general theme of the
meeting will be "The Volunteer and
His Work." The speakers will be
Dr. Richard C. Cabot and Mrs.
John M. Glenn. The latter is well
known for her writings and social
activities. Dr. Cabot is the distinguished superintendent 'of the Massachusetts General Hospital, and
the founder of the Hospital Social
Service Department. He is also the
author of books and articles on social service as related to the medical
profession. The public is invited to
attend the meeting.

Musical Clubs.

The Glee Club held its first rehearsal last Wednesday week at
o'clock. The attendance was very
good for the first meeting, and the
officers are in hopes that it will continue. Several of the Hopkins
songs were practiced and the result
was pronounced 0. K. The coming season promises to be a very
successful one for the Musical
Clubs, and new men are urged not
to neglect an opportunity to become
members. Freshmen who sing tenor
or second bass are especially desirable acquisitions. Rehearsals will
be held regularly every Wednesday
at one o'clock.

UNIVERSITY CALENDAR

Henry Thomas, ex-'15, is now at
the Bank of Baltimore.
Herbert M. Brune, A. B. '87, is
an attorney in Baltimore.
W. Berry Waters, ex-'io, is with
the Baltimore, Chesapeake and Atlantic Steamship Company.
Prom the Class of '07, Edmund
C. Lynch is with George H. Burr,
brokers, Wall street, New York.
It is reported that Woodrow Wilson, Ph. D. '86, has been elected
President of these United States.
Thornton Edwin Vail, M. D.'II,
is assistant resident physician at his
father's sanatorium, "Elmcroft," at
Thompsonville, Conn.
The Alumni Association of the
Johns Hopkins University for New
York and New Jersey will hold a
smoker on Friday evening, December 13.
Arthur R. Knipp, '07, has been
appointed dean of the faculty of
Canton• Christian College, China.
This is the college at which Charles
K. Edmunds, A. B. '97, Ph. D.'03,
is president.
Rev. Whitford L. McDowell, A.
B. '91, who is pastor at Roland
Park M. E. Church, after the first
of December will be district superintendent of the Washington District of the Baltimore Methodist
Conference.
Frederick Jackson Turner, Ph.D.
'90, has been professor of history
at Harvard since 1910. He is the
author of "Rise of the New West"
(1906), and also monographs and
articles on American(and especially
Western) history.
Last week the marriage of Miss
Martha Virginia Sisson, daughter
of Mrs. Sisson and the late John B.
Sisson, to Dr. Thomas R. Chambers, A. B. 'o6, M. D. '10, took
place. Mr. Allan Dill, a classmate
of 'o6, was best man.
The new head of Sydenham is
a Hopkins M. D. 'io, Samuel T.
Nicholson, Jr. He is successor to
Dr. J. A. Wright. Dr. Nicholson
comes here from St. Louis, where
he was assistant in clinical pathology, Washington University.
Charles Keyser Edmunds, A. B.
'97, and Ph. D. '03, President of
Christian College, Canton, China,
delivered a lecture on November 14
at Clark College on "Some of
China's Physical Problems."
President Wheeler of the University of California believes that,
compared with the ordinary marriages made in heaven, the marriages
made in college are a great improvement.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 18, 1912

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure in announcing the election of
Mr. J. Saulsbury Short, as one of
its associate editors. Mr. Short is
a member of the Class of 1915, and
was president of that class during
the year 1911-12.
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to express its thanks to the author of
the article on Woodrow Wilson,
which was printed on the front
page of the last issue, and its regret that his modesty led him to
request the withholding of his name
from publication.
The St. John's Game.
"What though the field be lost?
All is not lost—the unconquerable will,
And courage never to submit or yield,
And what is else, not to be overcome."

There is no reason for drawing
'-anything but satisfaction from the
event of last Saturday's game with
St. John's.. _The tremendous amount
of enthusiasm which in the face of
almost certain defeat pervaded the
whole student body, eclipsing anything of the kind known in previous years, more than makes up
for the loss of the game and is
ample indication of the existence
of a "do-or-die" spirit which is
bound to lead to victory in the end.
This spirit persisted in spite of
every reason to the contrary, and
the irrepressibility to which it
bears witness is a sure sign that
next year, when our present raw
eleven have been seasoned into
veterans, we shall administer to St.
John's so crushing a defeat that
their victory on Saturday will pale
into insignificance.
There was not the slightest reason
in the world to expect that last Saturday's game would be a Hopkins
victory. The strong teams of the
Maryland Agricultural College and
Franklin and Marshall, which defeated Hopkins by heavy scores,
had both been whitewashed by St.
four-'
John's. St. John's had made .
teen points against Washington
and Lee and had held the Dickinson eleven to a tie score, while
Hopkins had not won a single
game during the season. The odds
were all against us; and the wonder
is that we did as well as we did.

It is to be regretted that the open
letter of the Cotillon Board to the
students of the University could not
be published in the issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER for November 18.
The standing rule of THE NEWSLETTER is to accept no letter for
publication that occupies more than
two columns. The letter of the
Cotillon Board, however, would
have occupied at least six columns.
Since no authority had been given
any member of the Cotillon Board
to insert the letter as an advertisement at the expense of the Cotillon
Board, the Business Manager of
THE NEWS-LETTER did not feel
justified in publishing the letter. It
was offered, indeed, by the Business Manager, to publish the letter
if it were condensed, but the Cotillon Board wished to have the. full
letter published.
Be it said, in conclusion, that
THE NEWS-LETTER is glad to receive letters on this or any other
subject; but that, as a simple business proposition, it is forced to reject letters of more than the specified length..

November 16, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
_ In regard to the letter from the
Skunk Development Bureau, should
strongly urge the acceptance of
their generous offer. Every one
knows that brains count more than
brawn and avoirdupois.
What saith Shakespeare?
The big Bull Moose may have his bull,
The elephant his trunk,
But when it comes to common scents,
My money's on the skunk.

Yours truly,

signed, etc." The petition was
placed in the hands of a member
of the senior class, and in less than
two hours fourteen seniors voluntarily signed it. No effort was
made by either Mr. Dickinson or
myself to secure signatures.
I regard the fact, that practically
every non-fraternity member of the
senior class signed the petition at
once, as conclusive proof that the
non-fraternity men were heartily
in favor of a just non-fraternity
representation upon the Cotillon
Board. I feel confident that if I
had made any effort to place the
matter before the non-fraternity
men I could have enlisted the
hearty support and secured the
signatures of more than 90 per
cent, of the non-fraternity men. I
made no effort to do this as I
hoped the petition would not have
to be used, and I thought the less
feeling aroused over the matter the
better. The subsequent course of
action of the Cotillon Board showed
that I had exactly anticipated the
situation. For the sake of harmony,
and as a compromise, the Student
Council conceded and conceded. It
finally went so far as to offer to
compromise on one non-fraternity
representative outright, and a second if twenty-five non-fraternity
subscriptions were secured. Even
this was turned down by the Cotillon Board, and the Student Council, although composed of a majority of fraternity men, felt that
it could yield no further, and broke
off negotiations. Mr. Dickinson
and I then, much against our will,
presented our petition to the Cotillon Board. This created another
storm of contention and one which
seems only to have begun.
In order to try to nullify the petition, personal attacks and misrepresentations have been resorted to.
Certain things have been said about
me personally in order to try to
arouse the discontent of some of
the signers of the petition. I unhesitatingly brand these ad hominem arguments as malicious falsehoods and am willing at any time
to meet the authors of the false
statements and explain anything to
the satisfaction of all fair minded
persons.
I drew up the petition solely because I felt it was necessary as a
means of securing for the non-fraternity men what justly belongs ,tID
them. I have not taken up the matter for any personal object, and in
spite of all reports to the contrary,
I will not under any circumstances
accept a position as a non-fraternity representative on the Cotillon
Board. As a member of the Student Council, I am ready at all
times to represent all classes of
students, and I am ready to champion any fraternity cause in the
same way I have in this case Championed a non-fraternity cause, provided I can be convinced that it is
equally just.

CHARLES LELAND GETZ.

VOL. XVII, NO. 7.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 18, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRISON CONFERENCE ENDS

LIBRARY IN GILMAN BUILDING

HOPKINS ROOTING WAS GOOD

ST. JOHN'S, 27; JOHNS HOPKINS, 7

Thursday Last Day of Convention—Officers Elected and Indianapolis Chosen
for Place of Next Meeting.

Rooms Will First Be Used for Classes,
but Later Books Will Be Installed
in the Structure.

Parade One of the Best Ever Held, and
Cheering Section at Homewood

Losers Have Best of It in Straight
Football —Great Crowd and Much
Enthusiasm at Homewood.

The annual meeting of the American-Prison Association, whose sessions started in McCoy Hall on
Saturday, November 9, came to an
end on Thursday, the fourteenth,
after a most beneficial series of
conferences.
The objects of this society are,
according to the program issued:
first, to improve the laws relating
to crime and their enforcement;
second, to study the causes and
methods of preventing crime; third,
to improve conditions in penal institutions, and, fourth, aid discharged
Prisoners in obtaining employment,
and in reforming their lives.
The addresses were made by authorities on all these lines and were
confined to these and subjects
closely akin. It seemed to be the
Opinion of many members at the
meeting that the criminal is responsible neither mentally nor morally;
this point was brought out by sev,eral speakers.
Among the persons who made
addresses were: Mrs. Maud Ballington Booth; John D. Lawson,
Dean of the Law School of the
University of Missouri; Dr. H. H.
Hart, Director of the Child-helping
Department of the Russell Sage
Foundation.
Election of officers for the comMr.
ing year (1913) was held.
James A. Leonard was elected
president to succeed Mr. Fred G.
Pettigrove of Boston. Mr. Leonard
has been for many years the warden
of the Ohio State Reformatory at
Mansfield, 0.
Dr. D. C. Peyton of Jeffersonville, Ind., was elected vice-president and Mr. Joseph P. Byers was
elected secretary.

Parker, Thomas & Rice, the architects of the Gilman Building, which
will be the first of the new Homewood quadrangle to be erected, have
not yet finished specifications and
building plans.
As soon as these papers are ready
the Board of Trustees will let the
contracts and the actual building
will . begin. It was stated in an.
article last week that the Gilman
Building was not to contain the
University library. Ultimately, the
library will be in this building, but
the rooms will have to first be used
as lecture rooms until the other
buildings are erected. Then when
the "quad" is finished the library
will be moved into the Gilman
Building.
It is understood that after the
contracts for this building are let the
Trustees will examine plans for the
four scientific laboratories and the
technical buildings. Drawings for
these are ready, and the Board will
hold a special meeting to consider
them in the near future. The Gilman Building will be the western
end of the "quad" and two laboratories on a side will form the north
and south sides. The eastern end
will not be closed until later.
Extending southwards from the
laboratories will be the technical
buildings in the form of another
quadrangle.
The contour of the Homewood
Estate will be preserved as much as
possible in the erection of the buildings. The tract is one of the prettiest natural parks about Baltimore,
and many of the trustees favored the
plan of erecting the buildings to
conform to the ground.
Few of the old trees on the estate
will be cut down, and the "quad
will have surrounding it trees larger
than the Old Elms at Yale.

Too much cannot be said in praise
of the great amount of college
spirit manifested by Hopkins, both
in the parade and at Homewood,
last Saturday. The better part of
the undergraduate student body,
with the exception of the players
and others who were acting in official positions, responded nobly to
the appeals that were made at the
mass-meetings during the week.
That a great awakening had
taken place at Hopkins was evident
to all, and particularly to the regular spectators at Homewood. They
contrasted the spirit shown last
Saturday with that at the preceding games at Homewood, and were
very much pleased with the difference.
A culmination of the spirit which
began to develop at Tuesday's
mass-meeting was reached on Saturday. The singing of songs during the intervals between classes
had much to do with stirring up the
enthusiasm displayed by Hopkins.
The mass-meeting at Homewood
Friday afternoon was better attended than any for many years.
Those who assembled at Homewood on Friday sat for more than
a half hour in the cold grandstand
after dark, cheering the 'Varsity
eleven as it ran through its final
signal drill.
Emrich's band was a decided success, and Manager Ellis Ellicott and
"Gus" Sattler should be congratulated on their choice. The parade
began assembling between twelve
and one o'clock, and although it
did not start until after half past
one, everyone joined in the intermittent yells and songs which were
given every few moments.
When the parade did start it was
at once apparent that it was the
best that has been held for several
years. New features were introduced, especially by the sophomore
class, a number of whose members
formed a kettle drum division, each
being equipped with large tin dishes
and wooden spoons, which were
used as drumsticks.
' The sophomores also had secured
a very vociferously blatant, cacoplionious goat, which was the principal feature of the whole parade.
Headed by Emr,ich's band the paraders started following in the
order of classes, although many
alumni were interspersed at various
points. Edward Novak was the
standard bearer of the seniors, and
they followed immediately behind

fter being defeated three years
in succession by Hopkins' teams, St.
John's College, the 'Varsity's oldest
and bitterest rival got vendrtta last
Saturday at Homewood, 27 to 7.
Forward passes won the game
for the cadets, and their work in
this department has not been
equalled on the Homewood Field,
except, perhaps, by Twig-g of_Western Maryland, whose long thrOWs
last season were spectacular and
won the game then. To Wilson,
the St. John's left halfback, who
threw the passes Saturday, belongs
the credit for the victory.
The throws were not for long
distances; they were not spectacular because of the distance they
made, but the were accurate, lefthanded, timely and sped like a baseball. The four winning touchdowns
had for their direct source a beautiful forward pass. Three times Mellon carried the ball over after receiving from Wilson, and Claude
carried the fourth.
Hopkins did not use the forward
pass successfully, however, but in
all other respects played on a par
with the Annapolis players. Hopkins frequently had the ball in St.
John's territory near the goal, but
the cadets' barrier was impenetrable;
end runs and line plays could not
gain ground, and the 'Varsity was
forced to give up the ball.
In a like manner, St. John's
worked the ball upfield to within the
shadow of the Hopkins goal. The
'Varsity line held, and St. John's
could not gain on an end run. It
was at these crises that a forward
pass was called and a touchdown
made. Once in each period the
Annapolis team scored. Hopkins
made its touchdown in the last
quarter.
Line plays, with Branham and
G. Penniman carrying the ball,
brought Hopkins up to within 12
yards of the St. John's goal. Tappan tried a forward pass, which
Mellon intercepted, and a groan
went up from Hopkins rooters.
Clayton received the ball to punt
out, but the Hopkins line broke
through, and a trio of linemen
blocked the kick. The ball went
over the goal line and in a minute
Frankie La Motte had it tucked
under his arm, saving the 'Varsity
from the ignominy of a whitewash.
Newspaper reports said that Liebensperger and Bridgman blocked
the kick. It was a hard play to see,
but the general opinion is that both

Federated Charities.

On Tuesday, November 26, at 8
P. M., the annual public meeting of
the Federated Charities will be held
in McCoy Hall. The president,,,
Gen. Lawrason Riggs, will occupy',"
the chair. The general theme of the
meeting will be "The Volunteer and
His Work." The speakers will be
Dr. Richard C. Cabot and Mrs.
John M. Glenn. The latter is well
known for her writings and social
activities. Dr. Cabot is the distinguished superintendent 'of the Massachusetts General Hospital, and
the founder of the Hospital Social
Service Department. He is also the
author of books and articles on social service as related to the medical
profession. The public is invited to
attend the meeting.

Musical Clubs.

The Glee Club held its first rehearsal last Wednesday week at
o'clock. The attendance was very
good for the first meeting, and the
officers are in hopes that it will continue. Several of the Hopkins
songs were practiced and the result
was pronounced 0. K. The coming season promises to be a very
successful one for the Musical
Clubs, and new men are urged not
to neglect an opportunity to become
members. Freshmen who sing tenor
or second bass are especially desirable acquisitions. Rehearsals will
be held regularly every Wednesday
at one o'clock.

Henry Thomas, ex-'15, is now at

Conference.

'90, has been professor of history
at Harvard since 1910. He is the
author of "Rise of the New West"
(1906), and also monographs and
articles on American(and especially
Western) history.

Nicholson, Jr. He is successor to
Dr. J. A. Wright. Dr. Nicholson
comes here from St. Louis, where
he was assistant in clinical pathology, Washington University.

'97, and Ph. D. '03, President of
Christian College, Canton, China,
delivered a lecture on November 14
at Clark College on "Some of
China's Physical Problems."

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure in announcing the election of
Mr. J. Saulsbury Short, as one of
its associate editors. Mr. Short is
a member of the Class of 1915, and
was president of that class during
the year 1911-12.

It is to be regretted that the open
letter of the Cotillon Board to the
students of the University could not
be published in the issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER for November 18.
The standing rule of THE NEWSLETTER is to accept no letter for
publication that occupies more than
two columns. The letter of the
Cotillon Board, however, would
have occupied at least six columns.
Since no authority had been given
any member of the Cotillon Board
to insert the letter as an advertisement at the expense of the Cotillon
Board, the Business Manager of
THE NEWS-LETTER did not feel
justified in publishing the letter. It
was offered, indeed, by the Business Manager, to publish the letter
if it were condensed, but the Cotillon Board wished to have the. full
letter published.
Be it said, in conclusion, that
THE NEWS-LETTER is glad to receive letters on this or any other
subject; but that, as a simple business proposition, it is forced to reject letters of more than the specified length..

November 16, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
_ In regard to the letter from the
Skunk Development Bureau, should
strongly urge the acceptance of
their generous offer. Every one
knows that brains count more than
brawn and avoirdupois.
What saith Shakespeare?
The big Bull Moose may have his bull,
The elephant his trunk,
But when it comes to common scents,
My money's on the skunk.

Yours truly,

JUNIOR.

signed, etc." The petition was
placed in the hands of a member
of the senior class, and in less than
two hours fourteen seniors voluntarily signed it. No effort was
made by either Mr. Dickinson or
myself to secure signatures.
I regard the fact, that practically
every non-fraternity member of the
senior class signed the petition at
once, as conclusive proof that the
non-fraternity men were heartily
in favor of a just non-fraternity
representation upon the Cotillon
Board. I feel confident that if I
had made any effort to place the
matter before the non-fraternity
men I could have enlisted the
hearty support and secured the
signatures of more than 90 per
cent, of the non-fraternity men. I
made no effort to do this as I
hoped the petition would not have
to be used, and I thought the less
feeling aroused over the matter the
better. The subsequent course of
action of the Cotillon Board showed
that I had exactly anticipated the
situation. For the sake of harmony,
and as a compromise, the Student
Council conceded and conceded. It
finally went so far as to offer to
compromise on one non-fraternity
representative outright, and a second if twenty-five non-fraternity
subscriptions were secured. Even
this was turned down by the Cotillon Board, and the Student Council, although composed of a majority of fraternity men, felt that
it could yield no further, and broke
off negotiations. Mr. Dickinson
and I then, much against our will,
presented our petition to the Cotillon Board. This created another
storm of contention and one which
seems only to have begun.
In order to try to nullify the petition, personal attacks and misrepresentations have been resorted to.
Certain things have been said about
me personally in order to try to
arouse the discontent of some of
the signers of the petition. I unhesitatingly brand these ad hominem arguments as malicious falsehoods and am willing at any time
to meet the authors of the false
statements and explain anything to
the satisfaction of all fair minded
persons.
I drew up the petition solely because I felt it was necessary as a
means of securing for the non-fraternity men what justly belongs ,tID
them. I have not taken up the matter for any personal object, and in
spite of all reports to the contrary,
I will not under any circumstances
accept a position as a non-fraternity representative on the Cotillon
Board. As a member of the Student Council, I am ready at all
times to represent all classes of
students, and I am ready to champion any fraternity cause in the
same way I have in this case Championed a non-fraternity cause, provided I can be convinced that it is
equally just.

CHARLES LELAND GETZ.

the band. Next came the juniors,
led by Lawrence Getz, whose makeup was one of the sights of the
procession. Besides an extremely
Dutch derby, he wore a gigantic
-yellow chrygurthemum. The sophomores followed close upon the
juniors. "Jack" Dewitt carried
their flag. The freshmen brought
up the rear, but in accordance with
precedent, did not risk incurring
the sophomore's wrath with a flag.
Eight or ten other class banners
of years gone by were carried in
the procession and helped out on
the whole color scheme.

Waiting to see our heroes shine,
Waiting to see our heroes shine,
While the fog of the yelling drives us
blind.
On the line, on the line, on the side of
the line,

behind,
As the 'leven's in the rear, we stop the
yelling here,

From the bare poplar by the gate
Stretch the white snow-dunes desolate;
And roisterous winds are racing forth
From the deep, purple-clouded north.
I wonder, love, if thou art now
Alone beside the chimney's glow,
Dreaming with maiden fancy free,
And dreaming, it may hap, of me?
—Harvard Monthly.
